mdRecord.dcterms:title: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (Tom Sawyer's Comrade) / By Mark Twain
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910
mdRecord.dcterms:description: "Mark Twain's tale of a boy's picaresque journey down the Mississippi on a raft conveyed the voice and experience of the American frontier as no other work had done before. When Huck escapes from his drunken father and the 'sivilizing' Widow Douglas with the runaway slave Jim, he embarks on a series of adventures that draw him to feuding families and the trickery of the unscrupulous 'Duke' and 'Dauphin.' Beneath the exploits, however, are more serious undercurrents - of slavery, adult control and, above all, of Huck's struggle between his instinctive goodness and the corrupt values of society, which threaten his deep and enduring friendship with Jim." -- From OCLC record for Dover Publications edition issued in 2018 at Mineola, N.Y.
SPECIAL COLLECTIONS: Newspaper clippings and post cards in envelope tipped in. Gift of Herbert Rebach.
